page.title: 12TREVELGUE HEAD
page.content: The original settlers on Trevelgue are thought to be the Celtic tribe, the Dumnonii, but two of the barrows are thought to date before their arrival in Britain. Occupation of Trevelgue is thought to have been continuous for about 8 centuries. This would have been from about 3 B.C. to 5 or 6 A.D. Trevelgue Head was a prime site for occupation. The combination of iron deposits,nearby woodland and its suitability as a port made it an important site and this is believed to be the reason for such a long continuous occupation, and also why Trevelgue was so heavily defended. As well as the number of ramparts their size (at least 3O ft. when constructed) contributes to Trevelgue's importance.
